abstract: In late 2007, E. Stanley O’Neal stepped down as Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive, and a successor was named for Richard D. Parsons, Time Warner‘s chief at the time. The departures of two prominent African-American chief executives rekindled a debate about what barriers still exist for black executives seeking a corner office.
lead_paragraph: In late 2007, E. Stanley O’Neal stepped down as Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive, and a successor was named for Richard D. Parsons, Time Warner‘s chief at the time. The departures of two prominent African-American chief executives rekindled a debate about what barriers still exist for black executives seeking a corner office.

headline.main: Wall Street Names on Black Enterprise’s Power List

abstract: Amid the negotiations over the stimulus bill, the Senate did not adopt changes proposed by Senator John D. Rockefeller IV that would have cut a big tax break for Verizon
snippet: Amid the negotiations over the stimulus bill, the Senate did not adopt changes proposed by Senator John D. Rockefeller IV that would have cut a big tax break for Verizon
lead_paragraph: A provision that could provide a huge tax break to Verizon is still in the latest draft of the economic-stimulus bill that is expected to pass the Senate on Tuesday.

headline.main: Big Verizon Tax Break Still in Senate Stimulus Bill
